the canals and shew that the lamellae were more dilatatious[?] 
of their wall - 
In <u>Polynemia<\u> where the canals are very short and the 
central cavity very large the ova are situated in the 
under wall of the cavity, according to Will - but this author 
enters into no particulars as to the structure of the wall
[paragraph].41. The Generative organs of the <u>Phanerocarpae<\u> have been 
much investigated - The general result arrived at appears 
to be that they are plaited tubular bands attached to the 
concave wall of a depression existing between the pillars 
of attachment of the stomacal membrane - that they 
are altogether separate from the central cavity - <s>and<\s> that 
the spermatozoa are developed in pyriform sacs opening 
externally and that the ova lie free in the substance of the 
ovarial band 
[paragraph].42. The structure of the generative organs in <u>Phacellophora<\u> is 
as follows : - The voluminous folded and plaited 
stomacal membrane is attached by four thick pillars to 
the under surface of the disc - The edges of the pillars are 
connected by a thin membrane - which is concave externally 
so as to form a sort of shallow depression or generative cavity 
but the central and some of the marginal parts of this 
membrane are produced into long plaited processes which 
hang far out of the cavity (fig. 18) Each process is a sort of 
sac communicating freely at its attached extremity with 
the cavity of the stomach - air &c passing readily from the one 
to the other - It is in fact a sort of eversion of the walls of the
